medium: Pen and ink on two wood panels
creditline: Gift of Mr. Marco Grassi, Class of 1956, and Mrs. Cristina Grassi on the occasion of his Fiftieth Reunion

texts.textentryhtml: These delicately drawn figures are on two panels that were once one. It may have been part of a musical instrument, on which the images of music-making with a conch shell, flutes, and a lyre would have been appropriate. Many of the figures are hybrid creatures, including the ichthyocentaurs (fish centaurs) that are deployed across the surface as in the Greco-Roman corteges of sea monsters that decorated sarcophagi or friezes. The central form may have been an escutcheon (shield with coat of arms). It is supported by harpies, their feet on turtles, with foliate necks recalling human figures emerging from vines that were common in classical ornaments Aspertini could have known. He transformed the motifs into new permutations of the bizarre that demonstrate his fertile imagination.

Otto Lanz (Bern 1865-1935 Amsterdam). [1] Private collection, New York

[1] Lanz was a pioneering surgeon who assembled one of the first collections of Italian Renaissance art in the Netherlands, which was deposited on loan to the Rijksmuseum after his death. The collection was not evacuated at the outbreak of World War II and caught the attention of Adolf Hitler and Hermann Göring. Lanz’s heirs agreed to sell the collection to the Nazi regime via Hans Posse (director of the Paintings Gallery in Dresden) in 1941. Lanz’s collection was repatriated after the war but remained property of the Dutch state, which determined that the sale had been legitimate. Several works were transferred to the Rijksmuseum (and, much later, the Bonnefanten Museum in Maastricht) while about 220 objects—mostly furniture, sculpture and bronze plaquettes—were auctioned in 1951. Princeton’s panels were recorded only in a draft inventory sent from the Rijksmuseum to Lanz’s widow in Switzerland on January 21, 1936. Efforts to trace their whereabouts during WWII are ongoing.
